--------------------------------------------------
Dear Vishal,
Hope all is well.

Please note that I am still in the process of compiling the information relevant to the renewal.

The process will be structured around two separate tenders: one for KSA, and a second combining UAE, Bahrain, Kuwait, Egypt, and Qatar.

The participating brokers for both tenders will be Nasco Insurance and Marsh Insurance. Aon may also be added for the KSA tender, subject to final discussion with the KSA admin team.

The timeline and process are as follows:


*	
	Prerequisite: All brokers will sign fresh NDAs prior to launch.

*	
	Prerequisite: All brokers will sign fresh NDAs prior to launch.

*	
	Tender Launch: Monday, August 18th, 2025.
*	
	Active Tender Process: The core process will run for four weeks, from August 18th to September 15th. This includes two weeks for proposal submission and two weeks for negotiation.
*	
	Final Review & Award: The week of September 15th to September 22nd is reserved for final internal reviews and awarding the business.
*	
	Target Completion: This schedule ensures all agreements are finalized ahead of the September 24th renewal date.

Once the relevant documentation is ready with the baseline spend figures, I will share it with you and Sangeetha.

Hope the above provides the necessary clarity.

Best Regards,

Hagop

From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>

Subject: Re: General Insurance 
--------------------------------------------------
Hi Vishal,
Thanks for your feedback.
I agree that the timing is on the lower side. However, please note that the framework is already well-structured and although the numbers are big, the risk profile is to a large extent uniform. The market is also quite familiar with our portfolio as they have been involved in either quoting, insuring, or reinsuring it previously.

The market is also quite familiar with our portfolio as they have been involved in either quoting, insuring, or reinsuring it previously.
Regarding the brokers, Marsh is the largest broker globally, and they have been performing well. As for Aon, they are a potential stand-in for the KSA tender only. They are the second largest broker globally, and the KSA team has expressed dissatisfaction with their current service level with the existing setup. If they request to disqualify their current broker, Aon would be a suitable replacement to maintain a competitive environment. We have good previous working relationships with key contacts on the Aon Saudi team, so they would be a logical choice. I doubt this will happen, but it's important to have a backup plan.
Finally, for the contract management element, we do not need to wait for the full policies. We only need a confirmation of cover, which can usually be obtained in 2-3 working days.
Please note that we cannot trade without a renewed policy. I will do my best to manage within this timeframe. If, after the work is completed, you have legitimate and real concerns, we can explore extending the policy for one month to allow more time. However, this is a decision that can be made later should the need arise.
Best to connect during next week to align on the process as Joe will be back from his leave also.
Best Regards,
Hagop

Dear Vishal,

 

As clearly advised in the prior e-mails, we are not inviting only a single supplier. There will be two brokers competing for the business and potentially a third for KSA.

 

Furthermore, note that the insurance broker will be approaching multiple insurers with guidelines set to avoid overlapping access to the same insurer.

 

Regarding policy issuance, it takes considerable time for compliance checks to be made and approved, as this needs to be done for all insured entities region-wide. There is a lengthy KYC and UBO declaration required that tends to cause delays. This is a requirement mandated by the Central Bank in the UAE, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority (SAMA) in KSA, and so on. As such, a firm order from our end, followed by a bound cover confirmation from the insurer, legally binds the contract. Unlike conventional agreements, insurance contracts are no longer signed and returned as was previously the case. This does not mean we operate without documentation; accounts do not pay without supporting details, and we have an internal audit done on a yearly basis.

 

Please understand that this is a group-wide tender involving multiple classes of insurance. I cannot just give you a list of requirements and leave the rest to you. There are technical elements, a deep understanding of the operational structure, and processes necessary, and which must be conveyed properly for accurate risk profiling; this is non-negotiable.

Regarding policy issuance, it takes considerable time for compliance checks to be made and approved, as this needs to be done for all insured entities region-wide. There is a lengthy KYC and UBO declaration required that tends to cause delays. Unlike conventional agreements, insurance contracts are no longer signed and returned as was previously the case. This does not mean we operate without documentation; accounts do not pay without supporting details, and we have an internal audit done on a yearly basis.

Dear Vishal,

 

As clearly advised in the prior e-mails, we are not inviting only a single supplier. There will be two brokers competing for the business and potentially a third for KSA.

 

Furthermore, note that the insurance broker will be approaching multiple insurers with guidelines set to avoid overlapping access to the same insurer.

 

Regarding policy issuance, it takes considerable time for compliance checks to be made and approved, as this needs to be done for all insured entities region-wide.

Regarding policy issuance, it takes considerable time for compliance checks to be made and approved, as this needs to be done for all insured entities region-wide. There is a lengthy KYC and UBO declaration required that tends to cause delays. This is a requirement mandated by the Central Bank in the UAE, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority (SAMA) in KSA, and so on. As such, a firm order from our end, followed by a bound cover confirmation from the insurer, legally binds the contract. Unlike conventional agreements, insurance contracts are no longer signed and returned as was previously the case. This does not mean we operate without documentation; accounts do not pay without supporting details, and we have an internal audit done on a yearly basis.

 

Please understand that this is a group-wide tender involving multiple classes of insurance. I cannot just give you a list of requirements and leave the rest to you. There are technical elements, a deep understanding of the operational structure, and processes necessary, and which must be conveyed properly for accurate risk profiling; this is non-negotiable.

 

That being said, I have no issue working with procurement; I agree with the "no PO, no pay" requirement, which is useful.

 

However, I will be leading the tender from start to finish while adhering to the overarching guidelines.

 

I will request an extension of the existing policies until the end of November, as I am not certain how much additional time will be required to onboard the tender and the suppliers to the Ariba system.

 

I will coordinate with Sonia for this matter.

I will coordinate with Sonia for this matter.

Hi Vishal,

Thanks for your feedback.

I agree that the timing is on the lower side. However, please note that the framework is already well-structured and although the numbers are big, the risk profile is to a large extent uniform. The market is also quite familiar with our portfolio as they have been involved in either quoting, insuring, or reinsuring it previously.

Regarding the brokers, Marsh is the largest broker globally, and they have been performing well.

Regarding the brokers, Marsh is the largest broker globally, and they have been performing well. As for Aon, they are a potential stand-in for the KSA tender only. They are the second largest broker globally, and the KSA team has expressed dissatisfaction with their current service level with the existing setup. If they request to disqualify their current broker, Aon would be a suitable replacement to maintain a competitive environment. We have good previous working relationships with key contacts on the Aon Saudi team, so they would be a logical choice. I doubt this will happen, but it's important to have a backup plan.

Finally, for the contract management element, we do not need to wait for the full policies. We only need a confirmation of cover, which can usually be obtained in 2-3 working days.

Please note that we cannot trade without a renewed policy. I will do my best to manage within this timeframe. If, after the work is completed, you have legitimate and real concerns, we can explore extending the policy for one month to allow more time. However, this is a decision that can be made later should the need arise.

Best to connect during next week to align on the process as Joe will be back from his leave also.
